Metadata.Title: Current Router Configuration Matches the Start-up Settings
Metadata.DirectLink: Current Router Configuration Matches the Start-up Settings
Metadata.Author: Serge Batchilo, Jason Taylor, Joe Basirico

Content.Data:
Applies to

  • PCI DSS Requirement 1.2.2

What to Check For

The current router configuration should match the start-up settings. The router settings should be the same if the router is reset.

Why

If changes were made to the router configuration but were not saved in the router configuration files, then these changes will be lost after the router is powered off or reset. If the changes to the router configuration are lost, then the router may revert to an earlier, insecure state.

How to Check

Compare the current configuration to the start-up settings for each router to make sure they are the same. On Cisco IOS, the command to show the running configuration is "sh run"; the command to show the start-up configuration is "sh start."

How to Fix

Refer to the vendor's documentation or tech support for detailed instructions on how to sync the current configuration with the start-up settings on your hardware. This should be very simple. Most routers configured with a web interface feature a button that saves the current settings as the start-up configuration, and some do it automatically when new settings are applied. This rule is really for routers configured using terminal commands, which may require a special command to save the current settings. Cisco IOS command for this is "copy running-configuration startup-configuration" or "copy run start." Most routers that use web administration interfaces save the configuration as the start-up settings automatically.
